title: Distributed Data Show 81: Searching For Success with Alice Lottini and Roberto Carrera
description:
ABOUT DATASTAX ENTERPRISE 6
DataStax  powers  the  Right-Now  Enterprise  with  the  always-on,  distributed  cloud  database  built  on  Apache  Cassandra™  and designed for hybrid cloud. DataStax Enterprise 6 (DSE 6) includes industry-leading performance, self-driving operational simplicity, and robust analytics.

Learn more at http://www.datastax.com/products/datastax-enterprise and https://www.datastax.com/products/datastax-enterprise-6

CONNECT WITH DATASTAX
Subscribe: http://www.youtube.com/c/datastax?sub_confirmation=1 
Site: http://datastax.com 
Facebook: https://facebook.com/datastax 
Twitter: https://twitter.com/datastax | https://twitter.com/datastax-academy
Linkedin: https://www.linkedin.com/company/datastax
http://feeds.feedburner.com/datastax 
https://github.com/datastax 

ABOUT DATASTAX ACADEMY
On the DataStax Academy YouTube channel, you can find tutorials, webinars and much more to help you learn and stay updated with the latest information on DataStax Enterprise©.  Create an account on https://academy.datastax.com to watch our free online courses, tutorials, and more.

introduce yourself okay sure I am a principal architect I've been with data stocks for about three years now just over that and I work primarily in the AMIA region so Europe UK of course and all this area and I work as a process consultant and I'm part of the professional services team so you get to see a lot of trouble I get to see a lot of trouble and I get to solve a lot of trouble or at least and I have been working with data sex just recently for the last six months yeah has been a very interesting experience and we were laughing because yeah we have gone through a lot of pain but also I never go as planned and but I mean there this is why we get paid as yours is to figure things out so that I mean we want to talk about that some so maybe tell a little bit about the use case we can't name names but I thought it was really interesting so tell yes so we're in the process of implementing a solution that will serve to the customers a lot of data in a very quick reliable way so what we alleys now for a long time have been mentioning and we are trying to solve these problems now one of the very interesting things that we have is that we are able to release very very fast so that's something that I found quite easy quite interesting because we have ragnar well we start talking about one single problem and right now yes no I think that we have to go live with four different because we can start thinking about well this is information that we have but how can we expose it how can we put it out there without actually training a very complex table models or carrying multiple tables or how do we make sure that we have all the information multiple times so it is bringing a lot of benefit to be using that Enterprise version yeah where we are balancing between denormalizing for time must use queries on the common query path as opposed to creating search indexes to allow this extra flexibility and accessing different ways so it's for each use case we are trying to do an analysis as to how the data is going to be used and that drives of course the choice of whether to go with the normalization or search and where to mix so denormalization I've always felt like there's a little bit of revulsion my god it's gonna create a lot of extra data but I mean you deal with this every day yeah and so what is your normal response to lead to normalization problems generally the approach to decide whether to denormalize or not is a consideration on how central that query path is to your application if you know that you're predictably going to query the data in this way and you know that you want to certain you want a really quick snappy response you want to be able to retrieve the data immediately then a native read is the fastest thing you can do of course right single partition key clustering column example and go and the structure in the key in the right way is really important to make sure that you can cater for these access patterns when when it comes to something that is a combination of criteria maybe the customer will be able to specify some of these but not everything or you can't quite imagine you can try to build out all the possible queries that will happen that's why new ones here the flexibility that search gives you all right yeah that's gonna lead into that so you decided to go a search because you needed an extra layer of flexibility so maybe describe that a little bit sure so we have very specific cases where we know for example we're talking about customers or product ID that's just we their normalized and we make sure we have all the data we need yeah so that's fine but there are cases where we are thinking about our sales associates or the people that are in stores and we need to have information about what customers they serve or what are the pros that they sell things that are not necessarily going to fit in terms of a primary key opportunity clustering columns where we say we have the why would you want to go down this approach because the idea of having data that is stored natively and accessible natively and also indexed in place so basically allowing the same date ought to be accessed in a more flexible way is radically different to having to maintain a separate indexing cluster and this is what CQ our syntax example of that from the same driver with the same syntax with same secure language that has got extensions to humble search queries and this really allows a seamless integration between normal securities like traditional ones and search enhanced ones so that's quite powerful and that's played out quite nicely for the teams I think working with Young's it seems like they almost don't make a difference between and I think that's very important because the
